name: Nadia Aseeva
subject: Biodigester Quotes
message:
Hello BioHiTech!

I have a couple of questions about your biodigesters:

1. Could you provide a quote for each one of the five biodigesters you offer?
2. How much do these prices change if we order in bulk?
3. What are the different payment options? 
4. Is it possible to rent a biodigester and pay monthly?
5. Could you please include estimates of all/any the other costs we need to consider? (enzymes, shipping, etc.)
6. How long is the lead time, and is there anything we can do to shorten this timeframe?
7. What are our options if we want to return the biodigester? 
8. How much will that cost?
9. Is the Cloud reporting included in the monthly cost?
10. Would it be possible to use a valve splitter on an existing water line to feed the biodigester? 
11. Would it be possible to collect the effluent through a pipe or tube into a collection tank for processing?
12. Is it possible to use a converter on a 110V outlet to service the larger models?
13. Could we recycle/reuse the outlet effluent and feed it into inlet water? Has this been done before?
14. Do you offer a buy-back program? If we are halfway through our payments, and for whatever reason we need to return it, would there be a way for us to recoup our investment?
15. Considering you may have some clients who have returned a biodigester in the past, is there a marketplace for used biodigesters? Would you be willing to sell one to us for a reduced cost?

Thanks in advance for your reply!

name: Jim Berry
subject: Profit from Plastic!
message:
Congratulations on bringing new technology to the US! In reading how refuge is processed it appears plastics are a part of the oversized materials that bypass your entire process. 

If so, this will draw to your attention to an as-yet little known American technology for the circular plastic economy that is drawing traction overseas and just beginning to gain voice in the US.  Dr. Swaminathan Ramesh, a retired Polymer Scientist of Livonia, Michigan, has patented a series of catalysts that transform the plastics made in greatest volume (PE, PP, PS) directly to fuel at a rate of about ten pounds of plastic per gallon of fuel for linear polymers.  Imagine, ten pounds of worthless, nuisance plastic can be converted to a gallon of diesel fuel valued at about $3.50. 

The process unit containing the catalyst is compact and portable. Put the plastic waste in at one end of the device (the plastic is now gone!) and from the other end flows a fuel that retains and stores most of the energy formerly in the plastic for use at a time and place most beneficial to society; a circular solution!

name: Jenny Wise
subject: Thanks for paying attention to climate change!
message:
Those of us who have been paying attention to climate change for the past decade or more have been trying to do the right thing. From buying local food and installing bee hives to carbon offsetting and buying energy-efficient everything, we are making an effort to leave our children… well, any inhabitable world at all. 

But this latest news -- that we have fewer than 12 years to avoid catastrophe -- has people like me frantically asking, “How can I do more?” I have spent the last month researching how to afford solar panels, how to get started growing my own food, and how my family and I can take the more difficult, costly, and time-consuming steps to living a more sustainable life. That’s how I found your site. 

**People like me are counting on experts like you to help us embrace sustainability.** I really appreciate the information you have to offer. I know other people are looking for it too. I wanted to share some of the other resources I found insightful, in hopes you would add them to your site as well. 

The Cost of Solar Power: You Can Afford It
https://www.motherearthnews.com/renewable-energy/cost-of-solar-power-zmaz06onzraw

Greenhouse Essentials You Need to Know
https://www.homeadvisor.com/r/greenhouse-tips/

How to Save Energy Having a Smart Home
https://getyeti.co/posts/quick-guide-how-to-save-energy-having-a-smart-home

At-Home Composting
https://www.improvenet.com/a/guide-to-composting-at-home

Eco-Friendly Tax Savings
https://www.1040.com/blog/2016/11/21/eco-friendly-tax-savings/

Thanks for considering my request. Please let me know if you’re able to use any or all of this information. Or, if you have any tips for me, I’d love to hear them. 

Thank you so much.
Jenny

Jenny Wise, information@specialhomeeducator.com

If this information isn’t useful to you, I apologize, and please email me so I’ll know not to email again. Thanks!

name: Ken Kalemkarian
subject: Food Digester Evaluation
message:
Good afternoon

My name is Ken Kalemkarian, and I am engineering intern with the Central Contra Costa Sanitary District. 

It has come to our attention that there are increasing Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) due to the uses of food digester such as your company's Eco-Safe Digester series. 

I have been tasked with investigating few key areas:
* General information about cost and customer base.
* General market trend in sale of units, specially in California, Bay area. 
* Gas generation associated with the digestion process.
* Is the process discharge  batches or continuous.
* Effluent quality, collection & treatment implications, etc. 
* strength of the waste in mg/L of BOD and TSS (total suspended solids). 

If there are any resource regarding the topic above relating to your product, please contact/email me.  

Respectfully,

Ken Kalemkarian
Engineering Intern 
Central Contra Costa Sanitary District
Phone: (925)229-7319
Email: KKalemkarian@contralsan.org

name: Randy Ferrell
subject: NobleCon15 / SRAXir - New Investor Relations Platform
message:
Frank,

I hope your week is going well. 

We introduced our exciting new investor relations platform at NobleCon15. I'm not sure if we had a chance to meet, but I saw your listing in the conference book and wanted to reach out to introduce our exciting new IR platform.

Our new IR platform, called SRAXir (www.sraxir.com) offers publicly traded companies unparalleled insight into who their shareholders and custodians are, revealing who is buying, who is selling, how much and when, and then enables you to communicate directly with your shareholders at their homes, offices, and wherever they travel online on their desktop and mobile devices. This is just a couple of the platform's features. There is much more that I can share. 

SRAXir empowers issuers to:

- Unlock stock buyers' behaviors and trends from your NOBO and SPR list.

- Manage and monitor return on investment from investor relations programs and corporate communications firms.

- Engage current and potential stock buyers at their trading desks, investor events, or at home on both desktop and mobile.

Insights
- Monitor shareholders behaviors from your NOBO list.
- Discover top market makers from your DTC analysis.
- Uncover trends over time from your buyers and sellers.
- Build an audience from your NOBO list, and launch programmatic display, social or hyperlocal campaigns.

IR Management
- Assign shareholder credit to investor relations firms.
- Track return on investment from investor relations programs.
- Give investor relations firms access to list analysis.

App
- Manage your investor contacts wherever you go.
- Scan business cards at investment events.
- Send presentations to current and potential investors.

Data
- Turn real-time conference visitor data into targeted cross-channel ads.
- Reach potential investors based on current stock buyer behaviors and trends.
- Target current stock buyers to promote a higher return from existing relationship.

The investment community is very excited about SRAXir. Everyone we share it with is very excited to begin leveraging this new technology.

Can we set aside some time this week or next to jump on a call and demo the platform?

Looking forward to connecting.

Best regards,
Randy

A 3-year lease on the machine
A biodigester that can process 15 lb. of food waste per hour

Complementary employee training
Machine that requires cold water not hot/warm water

Emma Jacobs

name: Rachel Epitropakis
subject: Green New Deal
message:
Hi! I'm Rachel, a recent graduate from Towson University holding a bachelor of science in Environmental Science and Studies. Earth Week is 4/20-5/10, and to celebrate, I am planning a Town Hall influenced by the Sunrise Movement (link at bottom). I wish to gather people of different backgrounds and beliefs in order find a common ground based on the Green New Deal policies. The landmark report by the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) released that at the current pace, the Earth stands only 12 years from a temperature increase of 1.5 degrees Celsius. Natural disasters deemed legendary will be outdone by far worse ones with time. Currently inhabited regions, retirement and tourist destinations will transition into regions that can no longer sustain life. The Green New Deal offers feasible solutions which attempt to prevent this from happening.

The Green New Deal proposes to fight climate change and social injustices around the globe. It is backed by the term "dominant alignment," which sets the political common sense on which both major parties operate, and can win sweeping victories over a decades-long time frame. A dominant alignment can only be achieved through strong public support, which then generates the necessary changes in policy to satisfy whatever it is that the public supports. My goal is to establish a political alignment based on shared values in order to reach a dominant alignment and lead us closer to the Green New Deal. I am formally requesting that you co-sponsor this event. I would also like to invite a representative from your business to attend so that he or she can educate local residents on how your technology has the potential to improve both the state of the Earth and of their local environments. I've done my research, and I know that your company is already doing some amazing work. We want your technologies in Maryland! We're just waiting on policymakers to give us the green light, and that's what the Sunrise Movement hopes to accelerate with meetings like these, formed by caring individuals like myself.

There will be small GND Town Halls like mine occurring during Earth Week all over the country, and most of us would agree that realistically, we must start small in order to produce big change. The location, date, and time of the event, as well as my contact information, are listed below. There is also a link to the event so you can view it on the map, and also RSVP!

Best,
Rachel Epitropakis
443-900-3236


Date: Wednesday, May 8, 2019
Time: 2-4pm
Location:
Baltimore County Public Library
Perry Hall Branch: 9685 Honeygo Boulevard Perry Hall, MD 21128
Parking lot - ample spaces; no permit required


Link to the Event:
https://actionnetwork.org/events/towson-green-new-deal-town-hall?clear_id=true

Link for information about the Sunrise Movement:
https://www.sunrisemovement.org/

Link for the Green New Deal:
https://www.gp.org/green_new_deal

I am exploring international waste management companies to see if we could work together on a new patented waste -to-energy technology. Our technology is designed to convert methane from various sources (landfills/waste water treatment/animal/coal mines) to usable energy in the form of electricity, pipeline gas or CNG. While at the same time reduce the cost of energy production, reduce emissions, and to significantly reduce processing plant maintenence.
We have successfully been awarded an Australian government Tax Certificate which allows us to receive a 45% cash refund from all monies placed towards the full development of this new technology. Our research partners are well noted in the carbon technology field as well as chemical engineering and have conducted many projects internationally with success.

companyName: Shenzhen Huanengxing energy conservation and environmental protection technology co., LTD.
subject: Project cooperation + equity cooperation
message:
Hello! The recent projects we need to deal with are:

1) disposal of obsolete MSW in landfill:

It covers an area of about 90,000 square meters and now stores about 1.8 million square meters of garbage. A large amount of landfill leachate and oversize materials are produced by perennial accumulation. After investigation and calculation, the total leachate production is estimated to be about 250,000 cubic meters. The total amount of light sieve material is about 400,000 tons; The total concentration is about 30,000 cubic meters. After the project started, the daily leachate production was about 120-150 cubic meters. Daily output of sieving materials: 800-1000 tons;

2) there are three counties with MSW processing capacities of 100tpd, 150tpd and 200tpd respectively. In addition: medical waste 2tpd+ kitchen waste 5tpd.

3) bulk purchase of urban mobile waste/biomass/roadside grass pyrolysis equipment, processing capacity of about 2-5tpd.

In recent years, China has been actively promoting the revitalization and construction of towns and villages. Many local governments have asked us to purchase mobile waste/biomass/roadside grass pyrolysis equipment in the hope of converting it into fuel.

 

Shenzhen huanengxing energy saving and environmental protection technology co., LTD.，Main business：

1) solid waste pyrolysis gasification (MSW/ biomass/sludge/plastic)

2) low temperature ORC generator (Marine diesel engine/hot spring geothermal/industrial).

our company has established strategic partnership with guangzhou environmental protection investment group co., LTD., shenzhen huarui asset management co., LTD., and shenzhen huahui financial leasing co., LTD. name: Arik Goodman
subject: Kaiser Permanente Waste Sustainability Challenge
message:
Kaiser Permanente invites you to participate in a waste challenge.  We are seeking innovative ideas, concepts, processes, and potential solutions that could be implemented to reduce the regulatory, environmental, and financial risks associated with our waste management and disposal processes in California. We are particularly interested in: 

	Simplifying waste collection processes and reducing the risk of disposal of non-compliant items in municipal solid waste via collection, treatment or disposal processes.

	Providing more efficient waste collection and segregation processes that simplify decision making for staff or others who generate waste.

	Utilizing innovative waste collection, treatment and disposal processes and technologies that enhance the amount of waste that is eliminated, recycled, reused, or converted. Kaiser Permanente has established a goal to recycle, reuse, or compost 100% of our non­hazardous, non-infectious waste by 2025.

If you are interested in learning more, please visit our waste challenge website at wastechallenge.kaiserpermanente.org.

I came across BioHiTech’s profile and felt it would be worthwhile to reach out and introduce myself as well as the firm.

For a brief overview, the TCA Credit Fund is a predominately short-duration fund specializing in senior secured lending, as well as bespoke investment banking and advisory services to small-caps located mainly in the US, Canada, Western Europe & Australia. Tom

Thanks and have a great day, 
Lexie

Adel-Alexander Aldilemi

name: Mark Harris
subject: Can I write an article for your website?
message:
Hello! I’m Mark from AwarenessToolkits.com (check us out when you have a chance!)

I’m writing you today to see if you might be interested in an article for your website on the topic of how to use everyday technology to help you lead a greener, more sustainable life. 

For example, want to compost but don’t have one at home? There is bound to be one close by, but finding it may seem impossible. Using a site like https://sharewaste.com/ solves the problem!

Or, what about when you have to get fast food but aren’t sure which option is the most sustainable? Having more information may help, and you can get started here: https://earth911.com/business-policy/fast-food-green/

There are loads of apps you can add to your phone to help with these and other issues as well!

I’d love to put together a quick article for your site that offers this kind of information. It would be original to your site and all yours for free if you like it.

Let me know when you have a chance, please and thanks so much!
Mark

Mark Harris
https://awarenesstoolkits.com/
mark@awarenesstoolkits.com

subject: Sugarbush Resort Food Waste
message:
Hello,

I'm interested in getting more information about the digesters. We are a large ski resort with several food and beverage cafeterias and outlets. Currently, a local food scrap hauler comes once a week to collect food scraps in large totes.

Our largest collection area produces upwards of 9000lbs per month with the weekends being much higher than the weekdays. We have two other collection areas that operate seasonally. Mt Ellen operates December-March and produces up to 2000 lbs monthly, and the golf course operates from May-October and produces up to 1400lbs monthly. What sizes would you recommend?

Our annual cost of diverting food scraps from the landfill is $6000. Would this be a more cost-effective approach? Can it process any certified compostable paper products?

Best,
Joel

name: Tarah Schroeder
subject: Digesters for a new project
message:
I am working on a large corporate project that is looking to use a digester.  Before we get to sizing, etc.  they want to understand if there are any limitations on putting compostable disposable containers in the system.  Please see below and look forward to talking further.

-	What is your rule of thumb for amount of food waste per meal?
-	What is your rule of thumb for amount of disposable container waste per meal?
-	Is there a limit to the amount of disposable container waste that your system can handle?  Are there any restrictions on disposable containers going into your system?  Can it handle compostable containers?  Is there a particular percentage that disposable container waste needs to be in relationship to food waste?  For example, does the waste going into the system need to be 60% food waste in order for the system to function properly?

Thank you and talk soon,
Tarah Schroeder

name: shawn arrington
subject: MCX Material Connexion Company Introduction
message:
Greetings,

I want to introduce you to Material ConneXion. For over 20 years, Material ConneXion has remained the trusted advisor to Fortune 500 companies, forward-thinking agencies, and government entities seeking a creative, competitive, or sustainable edge that helps clients create the products of tomorrow through smart materials and design thinking.
 
Material ConneXion maintains the world’s largest subscription-based materials library with over 10,000 innovative materials and processes, while our international network of specialists provides a global, cross-industry perspective on materials, product development, and sustainability.
 
Please let me know if your team or your clients are interested in discovering the material innovations of tomorrow.

Manufactured by Tide Ocean SA
Solutions made entirely from plastic found in the ocean, coastlines, and uncontrolled landfills.

• Today, many end products produced using recycled ocean plastic contain only approximately 30% recycled material and are then mixed with virgin PET to maintain performance. The company has developed a formula that reverses damage caused by UV rays and saltwater, allowing for end products to be made with 100% recycled ocean plastic without the need for virgin materials to stabilize performance.

• We have a process that engineers fruit waist to “vegan leather”
This is why I believe your company can profit off of its fruit waist by converting it to a usable product.

 https://www.materialconnexion.com/
 
Kind regards,
Shawn Arrington

name: Daniel Evans
subject: Soil - Waste Management Research Study
message:
Dear Biohitech Global,

I am contacting you as part of a NERC-BBSRC funded research project being carried out by researchers at Cranfield, Lancaster, and Nottingham Universities to identify the extent to which soil science currently contributes towards several industries, including waste management. We are particularly interested in exploring whether the research priorities of soil scientists correspond with the priorities identified by those within the industries we are investigating, and how soil scientists could better meet these research needs in the future.

We have created a short questionnaire, which should take no longer than 5-10 minutes to complete. We were wondering if you would be happy to circulate this within your organisation, and pass it on to others working in waste management which might be interested. We hope that this research will help to identify knowledge gaps and avenues for future research within soil science. If you are involved in more than one industry, please answer the questions from each individual perspective.


Link to questionnaire: https://cranfielduniversity.eu.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_2iu911f34OdiAw5

Yours faithfully,


Dan Evans

subject: Research interest in converting on-campus food waste to energy
message:
Hi,

I'm a PhD student at Colorado School of Mines. My research group is interested in submitting a proposal to the U.S. Department of Energy for a project in the "Optimizing Community-Scale Wet Organic Wastes" category of their 2020 BETO FOA (https://eere-exchange.energy.gov/FileContent.aspx?FileID=42150026-9f85-46dd-9db9-2f3da59a4213). Our goal is to implement and optimize a food waste management system at our school, and we think your BioHiTech Renewables system and/or Digester might be a good fit for reducing the costs of food waste management, producing high value co-products, and/or enabling system resiliency with changing food waste blends. If you're interested in collaborating, please connect me to someone who can work with my group as we develop a short Concept Paper over the next couple weeks!

Thanks,
Mikaela Algren

name: Sarah Wagner
subject: Williamsville Central School District Quote
message:
Hello,
I am working with the University at Buffalo in Buffalo, NY to reduce the Williamsville Central School District's carbon emissions. One of our plans is to implement composting at all of their 13 schools spanning from elementary to high schools. I was curious how much you systems cost to purchase, install, and operate. We are estimating about 300-500 lbs per week at each school of food waste, but are awaiting more accurate estimates from the District.

Thank you,
Sarah Wagner
